questions.question_text: At which of the following layers of the OSI model does compression occur?

discussion.content:
Rogue DHCP server is the most correct answer. The user's router is distributing its own DHCP leases to the hosts, causing conflict when these devices try to access the network.
Evil twin is incorrect. Evil twin is an AP placed outside a network disguised as a legitimate network point to gather sensitive information from baited users.
VLAN mismatch is incorrect, though the hosts past the user's router may not be able to gather VLAN data because of the router.
Honeypot is incorrect; a honeypot is deployed by a network to bait attackers into wasting time in a false network environment instead of the real one.

Selected Answer: A
Exacto, Server DHCP.

questions.question_text: A network technician receives a call from a user who is experiencing network connectivity issues. The network technician questions the user and learns the user brought in a personal wired router to use multiple computers and connect to the network. Which of the following has the user MOST likely introduced to the network?
Users report that the network is slow. Upon investigation, the technician notices all users are on one large subnet. Which of the following devices should be used to break up broadcast domains?

discussion.content: Routers separate broadcast domains. Next best thing is a Layer 3 switch. Which operates like a router.

comments.content: PS you also have to use logic in picking your correct answer. If L2 switch was the correct answer then L3 switch would also be correct because L3 switch does everything a L2 switch does and more. The test takers wouldn't put 2 correct answers when you can only pick one. So L3 switch has to be the answer logically.
Layer 2 for collision, Layer 3 for Broadcast
You'd still need a router connected to the switch for communication between seperate VLANs, essentially the router is the one breaking up the broadcast domain and not the layer 2 switch.

discussion.content: Why not Layer 2 switch? Also L2 swith can do VLANs! It should be specified that the device needs to do inter VLAN routing as well...no?

questions.question_text: Ann, a user, reports that her desktop phone is not working on one cable. However, that cable provides connectivity to her laptop. A technician determines PoE is not provided to the end device. Which of the following is MOST likely the cause?

discussion.content: A: PoE = VoIP, but without PoE the laptop works. This is due to transceiver mismatch. Crosstalk and Jitter would not give this symptom. Bad cable would not let the laptop connect.

comments.content: The cable provided *connectivity* to the laptop, *not* power.
D cannot be the answer as it says `However that cable provides connectivity to her laptop` so no short/open cable, cable`s fine. The only possible answer is mismatch.

discussion.content: It should be D. A is wrong. The only references I could find online to Transceiver Mismatch came back with fiber optic issues. Crosstalk and Jitter are unrelated to POE. A bad cable has to be the problem.

D is a reasonable answer if there's an open on pins 4/5 or 7/8. This would limit the laptop connection to 100Base-TX, but it would still connect.

Also, transceiver mismatch? What VoIP phones use fiber? Or most laptops for that matter?

I feel it is D because an Ethernet cable has eight wires. The blue and white/blue wires (pins 4 and 5) are used for the positive voltage (V+), and the negative voltage (V-) uses white/brown and brown wires (pins 7 & 8 on the RJ45 plug).

What is not mentioned in the question is a media converter. The transceiver needs to match between the media converter and the switch. I could be wrong but this is the best answer I could find.

https://community.fs.com/blog/understanding-power-over-ethernet-poe-media-converter.html

Has anybody ever heard or seen a RJ45 transceiver?

Option B and C are definitely wrong. And D can't be right because the cable works on the laptop unless we assume it's only making use of pin 1, 2, 3 and 6 of the cable (10 and 100BASE-T) and PoE voltage is running on the unused pairs and one or more of the pins is an open circuit.
If PC has connectivity it has to be D?

comments.content: If PC has connectivity, then it can't be D. If it were D then the cable wouldn't work at all.

discussion.content: I maybe wrong, but shouldn't this be duplex mismatch? Are there transceivers on a VoIP? When I think of transceivers I think of SFP SFP+ QSFP QSFP+, which deals with fiber.
this cant be right, transceiver mismatch would mean no signal on laptop, and fiber doesn't deliver PoE to phones?!

questions.question_text: A network technician has been asked to create secure private networks between a company's headquarters and several branch locations. The company has provided the on-premises equipment, but each branch has a different ISP. Which of the following technologies should the technician consider using to accomplish this?

discussion.content: A site-to-site virtual private network (VPN) is a connection between two or more networks, such as a corporate network and a branch office network

comments.content: hi...i have the same question....it seems that you are recently using this site for NET+ preparations...hows study going. i took the exam last month and did not pass
which Networking+ exam did you take? When I took the test it had all these questions on it and I took the older test version
did you review the whole 900+ question?

When I took the exam only the PBQ's were from this site; however when I took the A+ exams 90% were on here. Use this website to study and know WHY a question is right or wrong and dont memorize the answer without knowing anything.
hi, are many questions from the exam on this site?
I think it's because they all have different ISPs.
I think because if site A try to communicate to site B, they have to go through Head Quarter but if you have them all site to site, it can be direct connections.
